title: General RRatepol package description
text: computation RoC RRatepol performed using following steps: Assemblage age-model data extracted original source compiled together, .e. depth, age, variable (taxon) 1, variable (taxon) 2, etc. (optional) Smoothing assemblage data: variable within assemblage data smoothed using one five -built smoothing methods: none (smooth_method = "none"), Shepard’s 5-term filter (smooth_method = "shep"; Davis, 1986; Wilkinson, 2005), moving average (smooth_method = "m.avg"), age-weighted average (smooth_method = "age.w"), Grimm’s smoothing (smooth_method = "grim"; Grimm Jacobson, 1992). Creation time bins: template time bins window movements created. single run (individual loop) computed: (optional) Selection one time series age uncertainties (see section 2.1.1.2. randomisation) Subsetting levels bin: working units (WU) defined (optional) Standardisation assemblage data WU Calculation RoC WUs: RoC calculated dissimilarity coefficient (DC) standardised age differences WUs. Several -built dissimilarity coefficients available: Euclidean distance (DC = "euc), standardised Euclidean distance (DC = "euc.sd), Chord distance (DC = "chord), Chi-squared coefficient (DC = "chisq), Gower’s distance (DC = "gower), Bray-Curtis(DC = "bray). See vegan::vegdistfor details. choice DC depends type assemblage data. summary single run produced based moving windows Step 4 repeated multiple times (e.g. 10,000 times). Validation summary results runs RoC calculation produced. (Optional) Data beyond certain age can excluded. Detection validation significant peak-points. five -built methods detect significant peak-points: Threshold (method = "threshold), Linear trend (method = "trend_linear), Non-linear trend (method = "trend_non_linear), first derivative generalised additive model (method = "GAM_deriv; f-deriv GAM; Simpson, 2018), Signal--Noise Index (method = "SNI; Kelly et al., 2011).

title: General RRatepol package description
text: RoC calculated consecutive Working Units (WU). Traditionally, WUs represent individual stratigraphical levels. However, changes sedimentation rates sampling strategies can result uneven temporal distribution levels within time sequence, turn makes comparison RoC sequences problematic. various methods attempt minimise problems. first interpolation levels evenly spaced time intervals, use interpolated data WUs. can lead loss information density levels high. Second binning levels: assemblage data pooled age brackets various size (.e. time bins) serve WUs. , issue lower resolution WUs uneven size terms total assemblage count (bins levels higher assemblage counts). Third selective binning: like classical binning, bins selected size created, instead pooling assemblage data together, one level per time bin selected representative bin. results even number WUs bins similar count size assemblage. However, issue low resolution remains. Therefore, propose new method binning moving window, compromise using individual levels selective binning. method follows simple sequence: time bins created, levels selected selective binning, RoC bins calculated. However, brackets time bin (window) moved forward selected amount time (Z), levels selected (subset bins), RoC calculated new set WUs. repeated X times (X bin size divided Z) retaining results. RRatepol currently provides several options selecting WU, namely individual levels (Working_Units = "levels"), selective binning levels (Working_Units = "bins"), new method binning moving window (Working_Units = "MW"), summarised figure.

title: General RRatepol package description
text: Due inherent statistical errors uncertainties age estimates age-depth assemblage datasets (e.g. pollen counts level; Birks Gordon, 1985), RRatepol can run several times results summarised (Steps 5-6). Therefore, two optional settings available using age uncertainties assemblage data standardisation.

title: General RRatepol package description
text: run, single age sequence age uncertainties randomly selected. calculation two consecutive WUs (.e. one working-unit combination) results RoC score time position (calculated mean age position two WUs). However, due random sampling age sequence, WU combination result multiple RoC values. final RoC value single WU combination calculated median scores randomisations. addition, 95th quantile randomisations calculated error estimate.

title: General RRatepol package description
text: Variables (taxa) assemblage dataset can standardised certain count (e.g. number pollen grains WU) rarefaction. Random sampling without replacement used draw selected number individuals WU (e.g. 150 pollen grains).

what: Detection of peak-points in RoC sequence (Step 8)
title: General RRatepol package description
text: rapid change composition relative abundances variables within sequence can provide means comparing RoC sequences interpreting potential drivers assemblage change. detect significant peak-points RoC scores sequence, point tested see represents significant increase RoC values. various ways detect peak-points time series RRatepol able detect peak-points using five methods: Threshold (method = "threshold): point RoC sequence compared median RoC scores whole sequence (.e. threshold value). ROC value point considered significant 95th quantile RoC scores calculations higher threshold value. Linear trend (method = "trend_linear): linear model fitted RoC values ages. Differences model point calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 1.5 SD higher model (sd_threshold = 1.5). Non-linear trend (method = "trend_non_linear): conservative generalised additive model (GAM) fitted RoC scores ages (GAM= RoC ~ s(age,k=3) using mgcv package (Wood, 2011). distance point fitted value calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 1.5 SD higher model (sd_threshold = 1.5). F-deriv GAM (method = "GAM_deriv): smooth GAM model fitted RoC scores ages (GAM= RoC ~ s(age). first derivative well continuous confidence intervals calculated model using gratia package (Simpson, 2019). peak considered significant confidence intervals first derivative differ 0 (information see Simpson, 2018). Signal--noise method (method = "SNI): adapted SNI Kelly et al. (2011), developed detect changes charcoal stratigraphical records. SNI calculated whole RoC sequence peak-point considered significant SNI value higher 3.

title: General RRatepol package description
text: Birks, H.J.B., Gordon, .D., 1985. Numerical Methods Quaternary Pollen Analysis. Academic Press, London. Davis, J.C., 1986. Statistics Data Analysis Geology, 2nd edn. ed. J. Wiley & Sons, New York. Grimm, E.C., Jacobson, G.L., 1992. Fossil-pollen evidence abrupt climate changes past 18000 years eastern North America. Clim. Dyn. 6, 179–184. Kelly, R.F., Higuera, P.E., Barrett, C.M., Feng Sheng, H., 2011. signal--noise index quantify potential peak detection sediment-charcoal records. Quat. Res. 75, 11–17. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.yqres.2010.07.011 Simpson, G.L., 2019. gratia: graceful’ggplot’–based graphics functions GAMs fitted using “mgcv.” R Packag. version 0.2–1. Simpson, G.L., 2018. Modelling palaeoecological time series using generalised additive models. Front. Ecol. Evol. 6, 1–21. https://doi.org/10.3389/fevo.2018.00149 Wilkinson, L., 2005. Grammar Graphics. Springer-Verlag, New York, USA 37. https://doi.org/10.2307/2669493 Wood, S.N., 2011. Fast stable restricted maximum likelihood marginal likelihood estimation semiparametric generalized linear models. J. R. Stat. Soc. Ser. B Stat. Methodol. 73, 3–36.

title: Example of full workflow
code: library(tidyverse) library(pander) library(RRatepol) library(neotoma2) library(Bchron) library(janitor)

what: Download the dataset Glendalough Valley from Neotoma
title: Example of full workflow
code: gl_dataset_download <-   neotoma2::get_downloads(17334)  gl_chron_control_table_download <-   neotoma2::chroncontrols(gl_dataset_download)

title: Example of full workflow
text: , strongly advocate attention paid section ecological ecological group, well, harmonisation pollen taxa. However, subject workflow.
code: gl_counts <-   neotoma2::samples(gl_dataset_download)  gl_taxon_list_selected <-   neotoma2::taxa(gl_dataset_download) %>%   dplyr::filter(element == "pollen") %>%   purrr::pluck("variablename")  gl_counts_selected <-   gl_counts %>%   as.data.frame() %>%   dplyr::mutate(sample_id = as.character(sampleid)) %>%   tibble::as_tibble() %>%   dplyr::select("sample_id", "value", "variablename") %>%   dplyr::filter(     variablename %in% gl_taxon_list_selected   ) %>%   janitor::clean_names() %>%   tidyr::pivot_wider(     names_from = "variablename",     values_from = "value",     values_fill = 0   )  head(gl_counts_selected)[, 1:5]

title: Example of full workflow
text: Extract depth level
code: gl_level <-   neotoma2::samples(gl_dataset_download) %>%   tibble::as_tibble() %>%   dplyr::mutate(sample_id = as.character(sampleid)) %>%   dplyr::distinct(sample_id, depth)  %>%    dplyr::relocate(sample_id)  head(gl_level)

title: Example of full workflow
text: recalculate new age-depth model ‘de novo’ using Bchron package. toy example use iteration multiplier (i_multiplier) 0.5 reduce computation time. However, strongly recommend increase 5 normal age-depth model construction. Prepare chron.control table run Bchron present important steps preparation chron.control table. many potential issues issues solving focus workflow.  Predict ages
code: gl_chron_control_table <-   gl_chron_control_table_download %>%   dplyr::filter(chronologyid == 9691) %>%    tibble::as_tibble() %>%   # here we calculate the error as the avarage as the agelimitolder and   #   agelimityounger   dplyr::mutate(     error = round((agelimitolder - agelimityounger) / 2)   ) %>%   # as Bchron cannot accept error of 0, we need to replace the value with 1   dplyr::mutate(     error = replace(error, error == 0, 1)   ) %>%   # we need to specifify which calibration curve should be used for what point   dplyr::mutate(     curve = ifelse(chroncontrolid == "Radiocarbon", "intcal20", "normal")   ) %>%   tibble::column_to_rownames("chroncontrolid") %>%   dplyr::select(     chroncontrolage, error, depth, thickness, chroncontroltype, curve   )  head(gl_chron_control_table) i_multiplier <- 0.5 # increase to 5  n_iteration_default <- 10e3 n_burn_default <- 2e3 n_thin_default <- 8  n_iteration <- n_iteration_default * i_multiplier n_burn <- n_burn_default * i_multiplier n_thin <- n_thin_default * i_multiplier  gl_bchron <-   Bchron::Bchronology(     ages = gl_chron_control_table$chroncontrolage,     ageSds = gl_chron_control_table$error,     positions = gl_chron_control_table$depth,     calCurves = gl_chron_control_table$curve,     positionThicknesses = gl_chron_control_table$thickness,     iterations = n_iteration,     burn = n_burn,     thin = n_thin   ) plot(gl_bchron) age_position <-   Bchron:::predict.BchronologyRun(object = gl_bchron, newPositions = gl_level$depth)  age_uncertainties <-   age_position %>%   as.data.frame() %>%   dplyr::mutate_all(., as.integer) %>%   as.matrix()  colnames(age_uncertainties) <- gl_level$sample_id  gl_level_predicted <-   gl_level %>%   dplyr::mutate(     age = apply(       age_uncertainties, 2,       stats::quantile,       probs = 0.5     )   )  head(gl_level_predicted)

title: Example of full workflow
text: use prepared data estimate rate vegetation change. use method binning mowing window, Shepard’s 5-term filter data smoothing Chi-squared coefficient dissimilarity coefficient. toy example quick computation recommend increasing randomisations 10.000 real estimation.
code: randomisations <- 100 # increase to 10e3  gl_roc <-   RRatepol::fc_estimate_RoC(     data_source_community = gl_counts_selected,     data_source_age = gl_level_predicted,     age_uncertainty = age_uncertainties,     smooth_method = "shep",     DC = "chisq",     Working_Units = "MW",     bin_size = 500,     Number_of_shifts = 5,     standardise = TRUE,     N_individuals = 150,     rand = randomisations,     use_parallel = FALSE # use_parallel = TRUE to use parallel calculation   )

what: Detect peak-points and plot the results
title: Example of full workflow
text: detect significant peak-points using Non-linear method Plot estimates showing peak-points
code: gl_roc_peaks <-   RRatepol::fc_detect_peak_points(     data_source = gl_roc,     sel_method = "trend_non_linear"   ) RRatepol::fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   data_source = gl_roc_peaks,   Peaks = TRUE,   trend = "trend_non_linear" )

title: R–Ratepol: Estimating Rate of Change in Temporal Sequences
text: RRatepol R package estimating rate change (RoC) community data time series. RRatepol written R package includes range possible settings including novel method evaluate RoC single stratigraphical sequence using assemblage data age uncertainties level. multiple built-dissimilarity coefficients (DC) different types assemblage data, various levels data smoothing can applied depending type variance data. addition, RRatepol can use randomisation, accompanied use age uncertainties level taxon standardisation detect RoC patterns datasets high data noise variability (.e. numerous rapid changes composition sedimentation rates).

title: R–Ratepol: Estimating Rate of Change in Temporal Sequences

title: R–Ratepol: Estimating Rate of Change in Temporal Sequences
text: Pollen data four European sequences Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) obtained. Taxa standardised taxonomically highest pollen morphotype (Level = MHVar2) using pollen harmonisation table Giesecke et al. (2019). Age-depth models developed using pre-selected radiometric control points provided Giesecke et al. (2014) calibrated radiocarbon dates using IntCal13 Northern Hemisphere calibration curve (Reimer et al., 2013). sequence, age-depth model constructed using Bchron R package (Haslett & Parnell, 2008) generate 1000 possible age predictions (.e. age uncertainties) levels. calculated median uncertainties level give probable age (default age) calibrated years present (cal yr BP, 0 = 1950 CE). sequence, excluded levels contained less 150 pollen grain counts terrestrial taxa, levels beyond 3000-years extrapolation oldest chronological control point. addition, excluded levels age older 8500 cal yr BP focus period substantial human impact.
code: library(RRatepol) library(tidyverse)  example_data <-     RRatepol::example_data  dplyr::glimpse(example_data) #> Rows: 4 #> Columns: 7 #> $ dataset_id        <chr> "4012", "40951", "45314", "17334" #> $ collection_handle <chr> "DALLICAN", "STEERMOS", "KILOALA", "GL" #> $ lat               <dbl> 60.38736, 47.80567, 67.96611, 53.00735 #> $ long              <dbl> -1.096480, 8.200150, 20.460278, -6.348035 #> $ pollen_data       <list> [<tbl_df[63 x 51]>], [<tbl_df[273 x 104]>], [<tbl_df~ #> $ sample_age        <named list> [<data.frame[63 x 3]>], [<data.frame[273 x 3]>], [<d~ #> $ age_uncertainty   <named list> <<matrix[1000 x 63]>>, <<matrix[1000 x 273]>>, <<mat~  example_data %>%   ggplot2::ggplot(     ggplot2::aes(       x = long,       y = lat)) +   ggplot2::borders(     fill = "gray90",     colour = NA) +   ggplot2::geom_point(     shape = 0,     size = 2) +   ggplot2::geom_point(     shape = 20,     size = 2) +   ggplot2::coord_quickmap(     xlim = c(-10, 25),     ylim = c(47, 70)) +   ggplot2::labs(     x = "Longitude",     y = "Latitude") +   ggplot2::theme_classic()

title: R–Ratepol: Estimating Rate of Change in Temporal Sequences
text: Estimate RoC values Dallican Water site using Age-weighed smoothing data Chord dissimilarity coefficient. Pollen data standardised certain pollen count age uncertainties Bchron used.
code: sequence_01 <-    RRatepol::fc_estimate_RoC(     data_source_community = example_data$pollen_data[[1]],     data_source_age = example_data$sample_age[[1]],     smooth_method = "shep",     DC = "chisq",     Working_Units = "levels"     ) #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RRatepol started 2022-07-26 15:44:23 #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RoC will be estimated between individual subsequent levels #> i 'time_standardisation' = 500 : RoC values will be reported as disimilarity per 500 years. #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RRatepol finished 2022-07-26 15:44:25 taking 2.04 secs #> #----------------------------------------------------------#  RRatepol::fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   data_source = sequence_01)

title: R–Ratepol: Estimating Rate of Change in Temporal Sequences
text: Now try standardise pollen data sample maximum 150 pollen grains use age uncertainties age-depth model. Process repeated 1000 times multiple cores using parallel computation. produce error wrapper showing 95th percent quantile.
code: sequence_02 <-   RRatepol::fc_estimate_RoC(     data_source_community = example_data$pollen_data[[1]],     data_source_age = example_data$sample_age[[1]],     age_uncertainty = example_data$age_uncertainty[[1]],     smooth_method = "shep",     DC = "chisq",     Working_Units = "levels",     standardise = TRUE,     N_individuals = 150,     rand = 1000,     use_parallel = TRUE) #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RRatepol started 2022-07-26 15:44:26 #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RoC will be estimated between individual subsequent levels #> i 'time_standardisation' = 500 : RoC values will be reported as disimilarity per 500 years. #> i Data will be standardise in each Working unit to 150 or the lowest number detected in dataset #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RRatepol finished 2022-07-26 15:45:56 taking 1.51 mins #> #----------------------------------------------------------#  RRatepol::fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   data_source = sequence_02)

title: R–Ratepol: Estimating Rate of Change in Temporal Sequences
text: Use Binning mowing window approach bin_size = 500 Number_of_shifts = 5.
code: sequence_03 <-     RRatepol::fc_estimate_RoC(     data_source_community = example_data$pollen_data[[1]],     data_source_age = example_data$sample_age[[1]],     age_uncertainty = example_data$age_uncertainty[[1]],     smooth_method = "shep",     DC = "chisq",     Working_Units = "MW",     bin_size = 500,     Number_of_shifts  = 5,     standardise = TRUE,     N_individuals = 150,     rand = 1000,     use_parallel = TRUE) #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RRatepol started 2022-07-26 15:45:56 #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RoC will be estimated using 'binning with the mowing window' of 500 yr time bin over 5 number of window shifts #> i Sample will randomly selected for each bin #> i 'time_standardisation' = 500 : RoC values will be reported as disimilarity per 500 years. #> i Data will be standardise in each Working unit to 150 or the lowest number detected in dataset #> #----------------------------------------------------------# #> i RRatepol finished 2022-07-26 15:49:38 taking 3.7 mins #> #----------------------------------------------------------#  RRatepol::fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   data_source = sequence_03)

title: R–Ratepol: Estimating Rate of Change in Temporal Sequences
text: Detect peak points using trend_non_linear method.
code: sequence_03_with_peaks <-   RRatepol::fc_detect_peak_points(     data_source = sequence_03,     sel_method = "trend_non_linear")  RRatepol::fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   data_source = sequence_03_with_peaks,   Peaks = TRUE,   trend = "trend_non_linear")

what: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
title: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
text: Taxa standardised taxonomically highest pollen morphotype (Level = MHVar2) using pollen harmonisation table Giesecke et al. (2019). Age-depth models developed using pre-selected radiometric control points provided Giesecke et al. (2014) calibrated radiocarbon dates using IntCal13 Northern Hemisphere calibration curve (Reimer et al., 2013). sequence, age-depth model constructed using Bchron R package (Haslett & Parnell, 2008) generate 1000 possible age predictions (.e. age uncertainties) levels. calculated median uncertainties level give probable age (default age) calibrated years present (cal yr BP, 0 = 1950 CE). sequence, excluded levels contained less 150 pollen grain counts terrestrial taxa, levels beyond 3000-years extrapolation oldest chronological control point. addition, excluded levels age older 8500 cal yr BP focus period substantial human impact.

title: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
code: example_data

title: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
text: data.frame columns: dataset.id - Neotoma unique number sequence collection.handle - Neotoma sequence name aberration lat - Latitude (degrees) long - Longitude (degrees) pollen_data - Data.frame contain pollen counts taxa level. sample_age - Data.frame including estimated ages level age_uncertainty - Matrix age uncertainties age-depth model

title: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
text: https://www.neotomadb.org/

title: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
text: obtained pollen data Neotoma database (Williams, Grimm, et al., 2018) using Neotoma R package (Goring et al., 2015). chose four European sequences (- D). sequence, taxa standardised taxonomically highest pollen morphotype (Level = MHVar2) using pollen harmonisation table Giesecke et al. (2019). develop age-depth models, used pre-selected radiometric control points provided Giesecke et al. (2014) calibrated radiocarbon dates using IntCal13 Northern Hemisphere calibration curve (Reimer et al., 2013). sequence, constructed age-depth model using Bchron R package (Haslett Parnell, 2008) generate 1000 possible age estimates sample depths original sampling resolution original pollen sequences. used 1000 draws build posterior estimates age uncertainty. calculated median age estimate sample depth obtain default age used following analyses. sequence, excluded levels contained less 150 pollen counts terrestrial taxa, levels beyond 3000-years extrapolation oldest chronological control point. addition, excluded levels age older 8500 cal yr BP ensure focus period substantial human impact.

title: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
text: Giesecke, T., Davis, B., Brewer, S., Finsinger, W., Wolters, S., Blaauw, M., de Beaulieu, J.L., Binney, H., Fyfe, R.M., Gaillard, M.J., Gil-Romera, G., van der Knaap, W.O., Kuneš, P., Kühl, N., van Leeuwen, J.F.N., Leydet, M., Lotter, .F., Ortu, E., Semmler, M., Bradshaw, R.H.W., 2013. Towards mapping late Quaternary vegetation change Europe. Veg. Hist. Archaeobot. 23, 75–86. Giesecke, T., Wolters, S., van Leeuwen, J.F.N., van der Knaap, P.W.O., Leydet, M., Brewer, S., 2019. Postglacial change floristic diversity gradient Europe. Nat. Commun. 10. Goring, S., Dawson, ., Simpson, G.L., Ram, K., Graham, R.W., Grimm, E.C., Williams, J.W., 2015. Neotoma: programmatic interface Neotoma paleoecological database. Open Quat. 1, 1–17. Haslett, J., Parnell, ., 2008. simple monotone process application radiocarbon-dated depth chronologies. J. R. Stat. Soc. Ser. C Appl. Stat. 57, 399–418. Reimer, P.J., Bard, E., Bayliss, ., Beck, J.W., Blackwell, P.G., Ramsey, C.B., Buck, C.E., Cheng, H., Edwards, R.L., Friedrich, M., Grootes, P.M., Guilderson, T.P., Haflidason, H., Hajdas, ., Hatté, C., Heaton, T.J., Hoffmann, D.L., Hogg, .G., Hughen, K.., Kaiser, K.F., Kromer, B., Manning, S.W., Niu, M., Reimer, R.W., Richards, D.., Scott, E.M., Southon, J.R., Staff, R.., Turney, C.S.M., van der Plicht, J., 2013. title: Pollen data from four European sequences the Neotoma database (Goring et al., 2015) — example_data
code: if (FALSE) { data(example_data) }

title: Calculate the dissimilarity coeficient — fc_calculate_DC
text: Calculate dissimilarity coeficient

title: Calculate the dissimilarity coeficient — fc_calculate_DC
code: fc_calculate_DC(data_source_DC, DC = "chord", verbose = FALSE)

title: Calculate the dissimilarity coeficient — fc_calculate_DC
text: data_source_DC Data.frame taxons columns DC Character. Dissimilarity coefficient. Type calculation differences Working Units. See vegan::vegdist details. "euc" - Euclidean distance "euc.sd" - Standardised Euclidean distance "chord" - Chord distance "chisq" - Chi-squared coefficient "gower" - Gower's distance "bray" - Bray-Curtis distance verbose Logical. TRUE, function output messages internal processes

title: Calculate the dissimilarity coeficient — fc_calculate_DC
text: Five -built dissimilarity coefficients available: Euclidean distance (DC = "euc") standardised Euclidean distance (DC = "euc.sd") Chord distance (DC = "chord") Chi-squared coefficient (DC = "chisq") Gower's distance (DC = "gower") Bray-Curtis distance (DC = "bray") choice DC depends type assemblage data. addition, RoC WUs calculated using every consecutive WU (only_subsequent = FALSE), alternatively, calculation RoC can restricted directly adjacent WUs (only_subsequent = TRUE). Using former increases number samples RoC can calculated within sequence, varies terms sample resolution, may still introduce biases related RoC estimation result varying inter-sample distances.

what: Calculate signal-to-noise index (SNI) for a charcoal record — fc_CharSNI
title: Calculate signal-to-noise index (SNI) for a charcoal record — fc_CharSNI
text: Code obtained Kelly et al. 2010

title: Calculate signal-to-noise index (SNI) for a charcoal record — fc_CharSNI
code: fc_CharSNI(CharData, BandWidth)

title: Calculate signal-to-noise index (SNI) for a charcoal record — fc_CharSNI
text: CharData Matrix input data one row per sample, containing: Column 1: age associated sample (yr) Column 2: charcoal accumulation rate (CHAR) sample (pieces/cm^2/yr) Column 3: threshold value (pieces/cm^2/yr) BandWidth = Width moving window computing SNI

title: Calculate signal-to-noise index (SNI) for a charcoal record — fc_CharSNI
text: SNI_output data list containing computed SNI related data, one row row input variable CharData: SNI = SNI computed sample winInd = indexes first last samples included moving window. E.g. SNI_output$winInd(X) == (, B) indicates moving window used calculate SNI Xth sample contained samples B, inclusive. popN = CHAR values samples noise (N) population (samples moving window CHAR threshold) popS = CHAR values samples signal (S) population (samples moving window CHAR threshold) meanN = mean CHAR samples popN stdN = standard deviation samples popN CF = "correction factor" used computing SNI.  Equal (v - 2)/v ,v number samples popN

title: Calculate signal-to-noise index (SNI) for a charcoal record — fc_CharSNI
text: function computes SNI described Kelly et al. 2010. Note data must interpolated constant sample resolution (yr/sample) input function. function makes assumption prior analysis input CHAR series, .e. background threshold methods may used.  However, input data still consistent interpretation CHAR value (column 2) greater corresponding threshold value (column 3) "signal" sample, whereas CHAR value threshold "noise". Refer Kelly et al. 2010 details discussion.

title: Calculate signal-to-noise index (SNI) for a charcoal record — fc_CharSNI
text: Kelly RF, Higuera PE, Barrett CM, Feng Sheng H. 2011 signal--noise index quantify potential peak detection sediment-charcoal records. Quat. Res. 75, 11–17. (doi:10.1016/j.yqres.2010.07.011)

title: Detect significant peak points — fc_detect_peak_points
code: fc_detect_peak_points(   data_source,   sel_method = c("trend_linear", "trend_non_linear", "threshold", "GAM_deriv", "SNI"),   method = NULL,   sd_threshold = 2 )

title: Detect significant peak points — fc_detect_peak_points
text: data_source Data.frame. Output fc_estimate_RoC function sel_method Character. method use peak-poit detection: "threshold" - point RoC sequence compared median RoC scores whole sequence (.e. threshold value). RoC value point considered significant 95th quantile RoC scores calculations higher threshold value. "trend_linear" - linear model fitted RoC values ages. Differences model point calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 2 SD higher model (sd_threshold = 2). "trend_non_linear" - conservative generalised additive model (GAM) fitted RoC scores ages (GAM = RoC ~ s(age, k = 3) using mgcv package (Wood, 2011). distance point fitted value calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 2 SD higher model (sd_threshold = 2). method  sd_threshold Numeric. Threshold SD residuals compared , determine peak-point (default = 2)

title: Detect significant peak points — fc_detect_peak_points
text: rapid change composition relative abundances variables within sequence can provide means comparing RoC sequences interpreting potential drivers assemblage change. detect significant peak-points RoC scores sequence, point tested see represents significant increase RoC values. various ways detect peak-points time series R-Ratepol able detect peak-points using five methods: Threshold (sel_method = "threshold") - point RoC sequence compared median RoC scores whole sequence (.e. threshold value). ROC value point considered significant 95th quantile RoC scores calculations higher threshold value. Linear trend (sel_method = "trend_linear") - linear model fitted RoC values ages. Differences model point calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 2 SD higher model (sd_threshold = 2). Non-linear trend (sel_method = "trend_non_linear") - conservative generalised additive model (GAM) fitted RoC scores ages (GAM = RoC ~ s(age, k = 3) using mgcv package (Wood, 2011). distance point fitted value calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 2 SD higher model (sd_threshold = 2). F-deriv GAM  (sel_method = "GAM_deriv") - smooth GAM model fitted RoC scores ages (GAM = RoC ~ s(age). first derivative well continuous confidence intervals calculated model using gratia package (Simpson, 2019). peak considered significant confidence intervals first derivative differ 0 (information see Simpson, 2018). Signal--noise method (sel_method = "SNI") - adapted SNI Kelly et al. (2011), developed detect changes charcoal stratigraphical records. SNI calculated whole RoC sequence peak-point considered significant SNI value higher 3.

title: Detect significant peak points — fc_detect_peak_points
text: Kelly, R.F., Higuera, P.E., Barrett, C.M., Feng Sheng, H., 2011. signal--noise index quantify potential peak detection sediment-charcoal records. Quat. Res. 75, 11–17. Simpson, G.L., 2019. gratia: graceful'ggplot'–based graphics functions GAMs fitted using “mgcv.” R Packag. version 0.2–1. Simpson, G.L., 2018. Modelling palaeoecological time series using generalised additive models. Front. Ecol. Evol. 6, 1–21. Wood, S.N., 2011. Fast stable restricted maximum likelihood marginal likelihood estimation semiparametric generalized linear models. J. R. Stat. Soc. Ser. B Stat. Methodol. 73, 3–36.

title: Detect significant peak points — fc_detect_peak_points
code: if (FALSE) { example_data <- RRatepol::example_data  sequence_01 <-   fc_estimate_RoC(     data_source_community = example_data$pollen_data[[1]],     data_source_age = example_data$sample_age[[1]],     age_uncertainty = FALSE,     smooth_method = "shep",     Working_Units = "MW",     rand = 1e3,     treads = TRUE,     DC = "chisq"   )  sequence_01_peak <-   fc_detect_peak_points(     sequence_01,     sel_method = "trend_non_linear",     sd_threshold = 2   )  fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   sequence_01_peak,   age_threshold = 8e3,   Roc_threshold = 2,   Peaks = TRUE,   trend = "trend_non_linear" ) }

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
code: fc_estimate_RoC(   data_source_community,   data_source_age,   age_uncertainty = NULL,   smooth_method = c("none", "m.avg", "grim", "age.w", "shep"),   smooth_N_points = 5,   smooth_age_range = 500,   smooth_N_max = 9,   Working_Units = c("levels", "bins", "MW"),   bin_size = 500,   Number_of_shifts = 5,   bin_selection = c("random", "first"),   standardise = FALSE,   N_individuals = 150,   DC = c("euc", "euc.sd", "chord", "chisq", "gower", "bray"),   tranform_to_proportions = TRUE,   rand = NULL,   treads = NULL,   use_parallel = FALSE,   interest_threshold = NULL,   only_subsequent = TRUE,   time_standardisation = NULL,   verbose = FALSE,   Debug = NULL )

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
text: data_source_community Data.frame. Community data species columns levels (samples) rows. First column sample_id (character). data_source_age Data.frame two columns: sample_id - unique ID level (character) age - age level (numeric) age_uncertainty Usage age uncertainty form Age-depth models. Either: matrix number columns number samples. column one sample, row one age sequence age-depth model. Age sequence randomly sampled age-depth model uncertainties beginning run. NULL - Age uncertainties available , therefore, used. smooth_method Character. type smoothing applied pollen type "none" - Pollen data smoothed "m.avg" - Moving average "grim" - Grimm's smoothing "age.w"" - Age-weighted average "shep" - Shepard's 5-term filter smooth_N_points Numeric. Number points used moving average, Grimm Age-Weighted smoothing (odd number) smooth_age_range Numeric. Maximal age range Grimm Age-weight smoothing smooth_N_max Numeric. Maximal number samples look Grimm smoothing Working_Units Character. Selection units DC calculated . "levels" - individual levels going used "bins" - samples predefined bins pooled together one sample selected time bin representation. "MW" - Bins selected size created, starting beginning core. repeated many times, time bin (window) shifting Z years forward. repeated X times, X = bin size / Z. bin_size Numeric. Size time bin (years) Number_of_shifts Numeric. Value determining number shifts window used Moving window method bin_selection Character. Setting determining process selection samples bins. "first" - sample closest beginning bin selected representation. "random" - random sample selected representation. standardise Logical. standardise == TRUE, standardise Working Unit certain number individuals (using random resampling without repetition) N_individuals Numeric. Number grain perform standardisation . N_individual automatically adjusted smallest number pollen grains sequence. DC Character. Dissimilarity coefficient. Type calculation differences Working Units. See vegan::vegdist details. "euc" - Euclidean distance "euc.sd" - Standardised Euclidean distance "chord" - Chord distance "chisq" - Chi-squared coefficient "gower" - Gower's distance "bray" - Bray-Curtis distance tranform_to_proportions Logical. community data transformed proportion calculations? rand Numeric. Number runs used randomisation. treads  use_parallel Preference usage parallel computation randomisation [value] - selected number cores TRUE - automatically selected number cores FALSE - use parallel computation (single core) interest_threshold Numeric. Optional. Age, results RoC excluded. only_subsequent only_subsequent = TRUE kept current version. time_standardisation Numeric. Units scaling result RoC values. example, time_standardisation = 100, RoC reported dissimilarity per 100 yr. verbose Logical. TRUE, function output messages internal processes Debug Use verbose instead.

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
text: R-Ratepol written R package includes range possible settings including novel method evaluate RoC single stratigraphical sequence using assemblage data age uncertainties level. multiple built-dissimilarity coefficients (DC) different types assemblage data, various levels data smoothing can applied depending type variance data. addition, R-Ratepol can use randomisation, accompanied use age uncertainties level taxon standardisation detect RoC patterns datasets high data noise variability (.e. numerous rapid changes composition sedimentation rates). computation RoC R-Ratepol performed using following steps: Assemblage age-model data extracted original source compiled together, .e. depth, age, variable (taxon) 1, variable (taxon) 2, etc. (optional) Smoothing assemblage data: variable within assemblage data smoothed using one five -built smoothing methods: none (smooth_method = "none") Shepard's 5-term filter (smooth_method = "shep"; Davis, 1986; Wilkinson, 2005) moving average ´(smooth_method = "m.avg"}) age-weighted average (smooth_method = "age.w") Grimm's smoothing (smooth_method = "grim"; Grimm Jacobson, 1992) Creation time bins: template time bins window movements created. single run (individual loop) computed: (optional) Selection one time series age uncertainties (see section randomisation) Subsetting levels bin: working units (WU) defined (optional) Standardisation assemblage data WU summary single run produced based moving windows Calculation RoC WUs: RoC calculated dissimilarity coefficient (DC) standardised age differences WUs. Five -built dissimilarity coefficients available: Euclidean distance (DC = "euc") standardised Euclidean distance (DC = "euc.sd") Chord distance (DC = "chord") Chi-squared coefficient (DC = "chisq") Gower's distance (DC = "gower") Bray-Curtis distance (DC = "bray") Step 4 repeated multiple times (e.g. 10,000 times). Validation summary results runs RoC calculation produced. (Optional) Data beyond certain age can excluded.

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
text: RoC calculated consecutive Working Units (WU). Traditionally, WUs represent individual stratigraphical levels. However, changes sedimentation rates sampling strategies can result uneven temporal distribution levels within time sequence, turn makes comparison RoC sequences problematic. various methods attempt minimise problems. first interpolation levels evenly spaced time intervals, use interpolated data WUs. can lead loss information density levels high. Second binning levels: assemblage data pooled age brackets various size (.e. time bins) serve WUs. , issue lower resolution WUs uneven size terms total assemblage count (bins levels higher assemblage counts). Third selective binning: like classical binning, bins selected size created, instead pooling assemblage data together, one level per time bin selected representative bin. results even number WUs bins similar count size assemblage. However, issue low resolution remains. Therefore, propose new method binning moving window, compromise using individual levels selective binning. method follows simple sequence: time bins created, levels selected selective binning, RoC bins calculated. However, brackets time bin (window) moved forward selected amount time (Z), levels selected (subset bins), RoC calculated new set WUs. repeated X times (X bin size divided Z) retaining results. R-Ratepol currently provides several options selecting WU, namely ndividual levels (Working_Units = "levels"), selective binning levels (Working_Units = "bins"), new method binning moving window (Working_Units = "MW")

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
text: Due inherent statistical errors uncertainties age estimates age-depth assemblage datasets (e.g. pollen counts level; Birks Gordon, 1985), R-Ratepol can run several times results summarised (Steps 5-6). Therefore, two optional settings available using age uncertainties assemblage data standardisation.

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
text: run, single age sequence age uncertainties randomly selected. calculation two consecutive WUs (.e. one working-unit combination) results RoC score time position (calculated mean age position two WUs). However, due random sampling age sequence, WU combination result multiple RoC values. final RoC value single WU combination calculated median scores randomisations. addition, 95th quantile randomisations calculated error estimate.

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
text: Taxa assemblage dataset can standardised certain count (e.g. number pollen grains WU) rarefaction. Random sampling without replacement used draw selected number individuals WU (e.g. 150 pollen grains).

title: RRatepol: Estimate rate of change — fc_estimate_RoC
text: Birks, H.J.B., Gordon, .D., 1985. Numerical Methods Quaternary Pollen Analysis. Academic Press, London. Davis, J.C., 1986. Statistics Data Analysis Geology, 2nd edn. ed. J. Wiley & Sons, New York. Grimm, E.C., Jacobson, G.L., 1992. Fossil-pollen evidence abrupt climate changes past 18000 years eastern North America. Clim. Dyn. 6, 179–184. Wilkinson, L., 2005. Grammar Graphics. Springer-Verlag, New York, USA 37.

text: data_source Data.frame. Output fc_estimate_RoC function age_threshold Numeric. Cut-value used maximum age. Roc_threshold Numeric Cut-value used maximum RoC value. Peaks Logical. peak-points presented dataset Peaks == TRUE, peak points displayed trend peak-points presented dataset Peaks == TRUE, one three method can used visualise process peak detection: "threshold" - point RoC sequence compared median RoC scores whole sequence (.e. threshold value). ROC value point considered significant 95th quantile RoC scores calculations higher threshold value. "trend_linear" -  linear model fitted RoC values ages. Differences model point calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 2 SD higher model. "trend_non_linear" - conservative generalised additive model (GAM) fitted RoC scores ages (GAM = RoC ~ s(age, k = 3) using mgcv package (Wood, 2011). distance point fitted value calculated (residuals). standard deviation (SD) calculated residuals. peak considered significant 2 SD higher model.

title: Function to plot the Rate-of-Change sequence — fc_plot_RoC_sequence
code: if (FALSE) {  example_data <- RRatepol::example_data  # example 1 sequence_01 <-   fc_estimate_RoC(     data_source_community = example_data$pollen_data[[1]],     data_source_age = example_data$sample_age[[1]],     age_uncertainty = FALSE,     smooth_method = "shep",     Working_Units = "MW",     rand = 1e3,     treads = TRUE,     DC = "chisq"   )  fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   sequence_01,   age_threshold = 8e3,   Roc_threshold = 1 )  # example 2 sequence_02 <-   fc_estimate_RoC(     data_source_community = example_data$pollen_data[[2]],     data_source_age = example_data$sample_age[[2]],     age_uncertainty = FALSE,     smooth_method = "shep",     Working_Units = "MW",     rand = 1e3,     treads = TRUE,     DC = "chisq"   )  sequence_02_peak <-   fc_detect_peak_points(sequence_01, sel_method = "trend_non_linear")  fc_plot_RoC_sequence(   sequence_02_peak,   age_threshold = 8e3,   Roc_threshold = 2,   Peaks = TRUE,   trend = "trend_non_linear" ) }

text: data_source Data.frame ROC Age sel_method trend used: "linear" - linear model fitted RoC values ages. "non_linear" - conservative generalised additive model (GAM) fitted RoC scores ages (GAM = RoC ~ s(age, k = 3) using mgcv package (Wood, 2011).

what: Overhaul change of the estimation of RoC
title: RRatepol 0.6.0
text: RoC score now returned units selected user (time_standardisation) Method sample selection bin now optional (bin_selection) RoC estimated subsequent bins (only_subsequent == TRUE) Bins now created form beginning core (instead 0)

title: RRatepol 0.6.0
text: General overhaul console outputs presented user running RRatepol information warning messages presented run

title: RRatepol 0.6.0
text: curated last years packages doSNOW snow replaced doParallel progress bar randomisation currently present

title: RRatepol 0.6.0
text: Added various checks correct argument selection hyphens replaced dashes (–) whole package examples wrapped dontrun

title: RRatepol 0.5.6
text: Figures now saved new folder (man folder) new names. cosmetics changes code (spaces, new lines, etc)

title: RRatepol 0.5.6
text: stop using pre-saved data decrease i_multiplier 0.5 speed vignette building change treads arguments fc_estimate_RoC FALSE vignette can build machines without multiple cores. rename r chunks remove empty spaces names

title: RRatepol 0.5.6
text: remove RRatepol namespace inside package internal functions fix couple typos function descriptions add cran-comments

title: RRatepol 0.5.5
text: sample.id sample_id can used sample identification RRatepol::fc_plot_RoC_sequence: fix typo argument age_threshold citation(package = “RRatepol”) now show correct citation update Figure README file
